Corn futures fell to a seven-week low and soybeans plunged the most in six years after the U.S. unexpectedly raised its crop forecasts, citing higher yields than anticipated.The corn harvest will be 13.686 billion bushels compared with 13.53 billion projected in July, the Agriculture Department said Wednesday.The soybean outlook also exceeded expectations.The government report surprised investors because the crop year began with record June rain in Illinois, Indiana and Ohio, washing away newly sown crops.Corn futures for December delivery fell 5% to close at $3.68 a bushel at 1:20 p.m. on the Chicago Board of Trade.The price touched $3.575, the lowest for a most-active contract since June 22.Soybean futures for November delivery slid 6% to $9.1325 a bushel, the biggest drop since July 7, 2009.Larger supplies of corn may reduce costs for ethanol refiners such as Archer-Daniels-Midland (ADM) and Valero Energy (VLO) and meat producers such as Tyson Foods (TSN), which buys grain for livestock feed.Shares of farm equipment makers fell on the news. Deere (DE), the largest tractor manufacturer, dropped 3%. AGCO (AGCO) slid 4%."This supply shock is more bad news for farm incomes," said Steve Nicholson, a vice president of food and agriculture research at Rabo AgriFinance in St. Louis. "It's going to be a tougher year than farmers expected, especially those that did not forward-sell this year's crop at higher prices."
Stocks were on pace for a flat to slightly higher start Monday amid mixed overseas action.
Nasdaq 100 futures were up 5 points vs. fair value, and S&P 500 futures were up less than a point. Futures on the Dow Jones industrial average were up 15 points in the stock market today.

The major indexes posted big gains last week, but failed to recoup the bulk of the prior week's sharp slide. Despite gains in the overall market last week, a number of market leaders such as Outerwall (OUTR), Vasco Data Security International (VDSI) and Taser International (TASR) got whacked.
U.S. stock futures still fared better than the mixed action overseas. The Greek stock market reopened for the first time in five weeks, plunging by nearly 23% before cutting losses.
But Germany's DAX and France's CAC-40 climbed 1% and 0.7%, respectively. The euro fell to 1.095 from 1.0984 late Friday.
Asian stock markets were firmly lower following weak manufacturing data. The Shanghai composite slumped 1.1%, and Hong Kong's Hang Seng lost 0.9%.
In economic news, personal income rose 0.4% in June, slightly above views for a 0.3% increase. Spending edged up 0.2%, matching views by Econoday. But that was the smallest gain in four months.
Factory data from Markit will be out at 9:45 a.m., and ISM's manufacturing report will be released at 10 a.m. Data on construction spending will also be out at 10 a.m.

In stocks, Tyson Foods (TSN) tumbled 8% in the premarket after posting disappointing quarterly results and cut its full-year earnings outlook. The company said its beef business suffered disruptions in the export market.

Irish drugmaker Shire (SHPG) said it bought privately held Foresight Biotherapeutics for $300 million. Foresight makes a treatment for infectious conjunctivitis, or pink eye. Shares were fractionally higher in premarket trading.Stocks were on pace for a flat to slightly higher start Monday amid mixed overseas action.Nasdaq 100 futures were up 5 points vs. fair value, and S&P 500 futures were up less than a point. Where's the beef sales? Tyson Foods (TSN) badly missed quarterly estimates and cut its full-year guidance because of high cattle costs and weak beef sales, driving its shares down as much as 11% Monday.The beef and chicken giant said fiscal third-quarter earnings per share rose 7% to 80 cents on a 4.3% increase in sales to $10.1 billion.Wall Street was looking for 92 cents EPS on $10.3 billion in revenue.President and CEO Donnie Smith said: "Unless beef market conditions improve rapidly, we will not achieve our previous guidance of $3.30-$3.40 adjusted earnings per share. As a result, we are modifying fiscal 2015 guidance to $3.10-$3.20 adjusted EPS."Based on its revised guidance, Tyson's implied fiscal Q4 EPS would be 83 cents per share. Analyst consensus is for $1 per share.The company said "export market disruptions" had an $84 million impact on Q3 results and it continues to see very high cattle costs "at a time when product values and export issues are making it difficult to realize expected revenue levels in this spread business."International sales fell after it sold its Brazil operations late last year and on weak demand in China last quarter, partly offset by stronger demand in Mexico.Like other companies, Tyson's chicken business has been hit by a shortage of chickens and high costs after millions of chickens in the U.S. with bird flu were destroyed earlier this year.Tyson shares were down about 9.4% to 40.19 in afternoon trading in the stock market today, Monday.Its stock was forming a flat base for nearly a month with a 45.20 buy point. It had been trading above its 50-day moving average and 10-week line, but fell below both after earnings results.Brazilian meat and dairy food processor BRF (BRFS) was down 1.5%.Among rivals in the chicken market, Sanderson Farms (SAFM) and Pilgrim's Pride (PPC) were both down about 1%, while Cal-Maine Foods (CALM) — the top-rated company in the group with a strong 90 IBD Composite Rating — rose 1.3%.Follow James DeTar on Twitter: @IBD_JDeTar.
Texas Roadhouse's (TXRH) earnings missed second-quarter estimates Monday due to higher beef costs, and the steakhouse chain lifted its food inflation outlook for the year.

Earnings per share dropped 9% to 30 cents, while Wall Street analysts expected an EPS increase to 37 cents. Revenue rose 15% to $454.7 million, above views of $451.1 million, as comparable restaurant sales increased 8.2% at company restaurants and 6.9% at franchise restaurants.
But Louisville, Ky.-based Texas Roadhouse now sees 2015 food cost inflation of 4%-4.5%, up from a prior view for 3%-4% inflation.
Shares tumbled 4% in after-hours trading, more than giving back the 3.5% gain made in the regular session.
In Q2, total costs and expenses climbed 18% to $423,000. Restaurant margin, as a percentage of restaurant sales, plunged 193 basis points to 16.2%.
Last year's drought in Texas and Oklahoma forced ranchers to reduce cattle herds, driving beef supplies down and prices sharply higher.

Texas Roadhouse CEO Kent Taylor said in a statement that "commodity inflation of 9.4%," mostly driven by beef prices, "resulted in earnings per share that were lower than the prior year period as it more than offset modest price increases taken in late 2014."
The restaurant chain also raised its projected capital expenditures forecast for the year to $145 million-$155 million from $135 million-$145 million earlier.
Texas Roadhouse has been grappling with higher food prices along with other chains such as Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG), which late last month beat analysts' Q2 earnings estimates by a penny.

In a conference call with analysts last month, the fast-casual chain said beef costs were relatively stable in Q2 but were "substantially elevated from historical levels and added nearly 100 basis points to our food costs compared to last year."

Also on Monday, meat processing giant Tyson (TSN) said it continues to see "very high" cattle costs. While its average beef sales price rose in fiscal Q3, sales volume and operating income both fell, due in part to a supply decrease of approximately 8%.Texas Roadhouse's (TXRH) earnings missed second-quarter estimates Monday due to higher beef costs, and the steakhouse chain lifted its food inflation outlook for the year.Earnings per share dropped 9% to 30 cents, while Wall Street analysts expected an EPS increase to 37 cents. Stocks ended modestly lower in a choppy session Friday, but still ended higher on the week. The Nasdaq lost a fraction, while the S&P; 500 edged down 0.2%. Hurt by losses in Chevron (CVX) and ExxonMobil (XOM), the Dow Jones industrial average fell 0.3%. Both oil giants reported lackluster quarterly results earlier in the stock market today. Volume ended lower across the board, according to preliminary data.
For the week, the Nasdaq rose 0.8% and S&P; 500 gained 1.2%. The Dow industrials climbed 0.7%.

Among leading stocks, Ellie Mae (ELLI) gapped up and surged more than 13% on strong quarterly results from late Thursday. The company reported earnings that rose 50% to 48 cents a share, compared to estimates for 32 cents. Sales also beat estimates — $65.9 million vs. $60.04 million.

Fitbit (FIT) jumped 5% ahead of its Q2 earnings report due Wednesday after the close. Analysts expect the fitness tracking device maker, which came public June 18, to earn 8 cents a share on a 181% sales jump to $319.5 million. Shares are up 15% from a 40.55 buy point of a short IPO base.

On the downside, Outerwall (OUTR) gapped below its 50-day line and dived 14% on late Thursday's disappointing Q2 sales. The operator of Redbox and Coinstar kiosks posted $545.4 million in revenue vs. views for $564 million. Earnings, which beat expectations, rose 44% to $2.19 a share. The stock fell more than 8% below a 78.04 buy point from a cup base, marking a sell signal.

LinkedIn (LNKD) gapped down below its 50-day moving average and sank 10% in heavy volume. The career networking site late Thursday reported results well above views, but its GAAP loss widened to 53 cents a share vs. 1 cent last year.

Wal-Mart Stores on Friday pressured meat suppliers to use fewer antibiotics, upgrade animal treatment and self-report abuses, following action by McDonald's, Tyson Foods and others.

The world's largest retailer is asking suppliers to report and take disciplinary action in cases of animal abuse. It also wants them to try to find better animal housing, alleviate painful procedures, improve slaughter methods and provide progress reports to Wal-Mart (WMT) and the public.

"We have listened to our customers and are asking our suppliers to engage in improved reporting standards and transparency measures regarding the treatment of farm animals," Wal-Mart Senior Vice President Kathleen McLaughlin said in a statement.
Wal-Mart stock fell 0.3% to 75.86.
Wal-Mart joins a growing crew of food producers and retailers taking similar steps.

Top U.S. chicken producer Tyson (TSN), whose brands include Jimmy Dean, Hillshire Farms and Ball Park, said in February it's working to end use of human antibiotics in domestic broiler chickens by September 2017.
Burger giant McDonald's (MCD) in March said that within two years it will use only chickens raised without use of human antibiotics.
Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG), a leader in the move to healthier food, buys meat "without antibiotics and synthetic hormones."

The fast-casual chain recently stopped serving carnitas in some locations, saying a pork supplier had violated Chipotle's standards on the treatment of pigs. It is also limiting the use of genetically modified ingredients.

Costco (COST) is working to end the sale of chickens given antibiotics.Wal-Mart Stores on Friday pressured meat suppliers to use fewer antibiotics, upgrade animal treatment and self-report abuses, following action by McDonald's, Tyson Foods and others.The world's largest retailer is asking suppliers to report and take disciplinary action in cases of animal abuse. Tyson Foods (TSN) reported second-quarter earnings Monday that topped Wall Street estimates, but sales fell short of views. The meat and poultry producer's Q2 earnings rose 25% to 75 cents. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters were expecting 72 cents. Revenue climbed 10.5% to $9.98 billion on the acquisition Hillshire Brands, but that was less than analysts' views for $10.1 billion.…
Stocks were poised for a higher open Monday amid mixed overseas data and more corporate earnings reports.
Nasdaq 100 futures rallied 8 points vs. fair value and S&P 500 futures logged 6 points. Futures on the Dow Jones industrial average gained 51 points.

Factory activity in China stayed in contraction mode for another month, as the final HSBC purchasing managers index (PMI) for April slipped to 48.9 from a prior reading of 49.2. Figures below 50 signal contraction. But the Shanghai composite climbed 0.9%, as the weak data boosted stimulus hopes.
Germany's DAX jumped 1.5% on mostly upbeat data. The final eurozone manufacturing for April came in at 52.0, up a touch from a flash reading of 51.9. But that was down slightly from 52.2 in March.

This week will bring another wave of earnings reports. Results from a number of IBD 50 firms are due. But before that, companies such as Comcast (CMCSA) and Cognizant Technology Solutions (CTSH) posted quarterly results that topped analysts' expectations early Monday. They were up 5% and 2%, respectively in the premarket. Tyson Foods (TSN) delivered quarterly earnings that topped views, but sales missed. Still, Tyson shares were slightly higher in premarket trading.

Elsewhere, Twitter (TWTR) rose more than 1% premarket after being upgraded to hold from sell at Stifel Nicolaus. Disappointing quarterly sales and a weak outlook sent shares of the microblogging firm plunging 26% last week.

SolarCity (SCTY) dimmed 1% premarket after Robert W. Baird downgraded shares to neutral from outperform and cut its price target to 65 from 76. The solar installer will report Q1 earnings Tuesday after market's close.
Data on March factory orders will be out at 10 a.m ET in the stock market today.

Tyson Foods (TSN), whose brands include Jimmy Dean, Hillshire Farm and Ball Park, said it is working toward ending the use of human antibiotics from its domestic broiler chickens by the end of Sept. 2017.
The move follows similar announcements from McDonald's (MCD) and Costco Wholesale (COST).

While the meat producer says it is confident that its meat and poultry products are safe, it has already taken steps toward cutting out antibiotics, including nixing antibiotic use in its broiler hatcheries and trimming human antibiotic use on broiler chickens by more than 80% since 2011. Broiler chickens are poultry raised for consumption.

"Given the progress we've already made reducing antibiotics in our broilers, we believe it's realistic to shoot for zero by the end of our 2017 fiscal year," said Tyson Foods CEO Donnie Smith in a statement.
"But we won't jeopardize animal well-being just to get there. We'll use the best available treatments to keep our chickens healthy, under veterinary supervision," he said.
The company said it will create working groups with independent farmers in its meat supply chain to address ways to cut human antibiotic use in cattle, hog and turkey farms.

In early March, McDonald's said that within the next two years it will use chickens raised only without human antibiotics. Costco told Reuters it is working toward eliminating shared-use antibiotics in animals.

Restaurants, food processors and retailers are trying to keep pace with a growing consumer desire for more natural food. Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) on Monday said it has eliminated genetically modified food from its menu, fulfilling a Chipotle vow from earlier in the year. Chipotle has faced carnitas shortages this year as its seeks a pork supplier that meets its standards for animal treatment.
Shares of Tyson rose 1.1% to 39.32 in afternoon trading in the stock market today.
Its stock is closing back in on its 50-day line after breaking support in mid-April.
Tyson said its antibiotics decision will not materially affect its financial performance.
Follow Elaine Low on Twitter: @IBD_ELow.
RELATED: Costco Eyes Sales Curbs Of Antibiotics-Treated Meat

U.S. corn supplies are even bigger than analysts were expecting, with prices tumbling the most since June after the government pegged inventories at the highest in 28 years. Domestic stockpiles at 7.745 billion bushels as of March 1 were 11% higher than a year earlier, the U.S. Department of Agriculture said Tuesday. That's the most for the date since 1987.…
The Dow Jones industrial average and S&P 500 surrendered early gains Tuesday, but the Nasdaq outperformed.
The Nasdaq rose 0.4%, but the Dow lost 0.4% and the S&P 500 gave up 0.2%. Volume was tracking higher on both exchanges in the stock market today.

The Dow was held underwater by DuPont (DD) and Travelers (TRV). Both issued disappointing Q1 reports. DuPont said a 15% earnings decline was the result of a strong dollar. Travelers' sales missed expectations.

Verizon (VZ), another Dow component, beat analyst estimateshttp://news.investors.com/technology/042115-748798-verizon-stock-falls-mixed-q1-wireless-earnings.htm, but added fewer core customers than Wall Street expected. It was down less than 1% after regaining most of its early losses.
Palo Alto Networks (PANW) was a bright spot. Shares plowed into new high ground with a 4% gain in heavy volume. Imperial Capital re-initiated coverage with outperform rating and a 170 price target.

Mylan (MYL) gapped up to a new high after Teva Pharmaceutical (TEVA) launched a $40 billion bid for the company. After it was reported last week that Teva would make a bid, Mylan said it was "fully committed to its stand-alone strategy." Teva was up 2%.
Among IBD 50 stocks, 36 were higher and 14 were lower. Mylan was the best performer, followed by Noah Holdings (NOAH). Shares rose more than 5%, also to a new high.
The worst IBD 50 performer was Under Armour (UA), down more than 4%. It reported earnings of 5 cents a share, a 17% decline from a year ago

Shares of poultry-producing monolith Tyson Foods (TSN) dropped Wednesday after the U.S. Department of Agriculture said it may have discovered a case of bird flu in poultry in Arkansas, where the company is headquartered, Reuters reported.The department cautioned that the case was not yet confirmed, and Reuters noted that a Tyson representative said there were no diagnoses of the virus in any flocks raised for the company. Avian flu typically is highly contagious and deadly among birds.Arkansas is the third largest U.S. turkey producerTyson shares fell 4.5% to 38.01 by early afternoon in the stock market today.News of the possible case, said to be identified in a turkey flock, follows recent confirmed cases of the virus, called H5N2, in poultry farms or elsewhere in Missouri, Minnesota, Idaho and the West Coast states.Minnesota, Missouri and Arkansas lie right in the path of the Mississippi Flyway bird migration route, which runs over the U.S. from Canada, Reuters noted. Affected states have taken security measures to contain the virus, which the USDA said has not been found in people.Shares of other poultry producers followed Tyson downward. Sanderson Farms (SAFM) slid 5.4% to 78.03. Pilgrim's Pride (PPC) tumbled 8.3% to 24.31.All three stocks were trading below their 50-day and 200-day moving averages, a sign of falling confidence in the companies among investors.

Buffalo Wild Wings (BWLD) saw red-hot sales gains at the start of its new fiscal year as the long-awaited college football playoffs kicked off for the first time. The sports bar chain, whose fortunes run in tandem with high-profile games and poultry-price fluctuations, said that its comparable-store sales for the first five weeks of the first quarter jumped 11.9% at…

Food shares are rallying as news of the Kraft Foods (KRFT) merger with ketchup giant H.J. Heinz is making investors' mouths water.Kraft is surging 41% near noon in the stock market today on the news that Heinz owners 3G Capital and Berkshire Hathaway will buy the cheese and snack maker.Shares of Oreo maker Mondelez International (MDLZ) — a Kraft spinoff — are up 2.6%. Cereal giant General Mills (GIS) shares ticked up 2.4%. Dean Foods (DF) rose 1.9%. J.M. Smucker (SJM) shares 2.3%. ConAgra Foods (CAG) shares edged up 1.4%. Kellogg (K) also climbed 1.4%.Natural food makers Hain Celestial (HAIN) shares rose 2.9% and WhiteWave Foods (WWAV) shares bumped up 1.7%, both hitting new highs.Campbell Soup (CPB) shares essentially remained flat, edging up 0.3%.Berkshire Hathaway (BRKA) A-class and Berkshire (BRKB) B-class shares edged lower.Looking further down the road, Mondelez, Pinnacle Foods (PF) and B&G Foods (BG) could potentially benefit from the merger, according to RBC Capital Markets analyst David Palmer.If Kraft moves to sell non-core businesses like frozen foods, Birds Eye parent Pinnacle could be a potential buyer, while B&G might eye Kraft's other non-core brands, said Palmer in a note.And Palmer speculates that Mondelez could be the next big acquisition target.According to a recent PwC report, merger deals may be key in streamlining increasingly large portfolios."M&A is likely to become increasingly important, not just in growing food companies, but in streamlining and focusing them," it said.Other recent food mergers include Tyson Foods' (TSN) acquisition of Hillshire Brands and General Mills' buyout of Annie's.Follow Elaine Low on Twitter: @IBD_ELow.RELATED:3G Capital, Berkshire To Buy Kraft, Merge With Heinz.
The ink hasn't dried on the Kraft Foods (KRFT) merger with H.J. Heinz, but analysts already are speculating which brands may be sold and which food companies are next on the M&A menu.

3G Capital and Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway  (BRKA), which acquired Heinz in 2013, said Wednesday they will buy Kraft to forge Kraft Heinz Co. Kraft holders will get shares in the merged company, plus a special $16.50 a share dividend, paid for by $10 billion from 3G and Berkshire.
Kraft stock rose 35.6% to 83.17.

Kraft Heinz would be the world's No. 5 food and beverage company, with eight brands topping $1 billion in annual sales. It would team Kraft's Velveeta, Lunchables and Oscar Mayer with Heinz's flagship ketchup and baked beans.

The combined company may look to sell a few noncore or regional businesses, said RBC Capital Markets David Palmer in a note released before Wednesday's official confirmation. B&G Foods (BG) might be a buyer. And Heinz's frozen portfolio, which includes Weight Watchers Smart Ones and Ore Ida, might appeal to Pinnacle Foods (PF).
Last year, Hillshire Brands axed its quest for Pinnacle after agreeing to be acquired itself by meat producer Tyson Foods (TSN).
3G's past gives some hints about which businesses might be cut.

"A fair amount of brand pruning could be in the cards, similar to the actions 3G has taken since owning Heinz (such as shedding Shanghai Long Fong Foods in China and the U.S. foodservice dessert business in 2013)," said Morningstar analyst Erin Lash in a note.
Jell-O's standing, in particular, might look wobbly.

"We've thought for some time that Jell-O, which continues to falter despite multiple stabs at putting it on more stable ground, could be axed in favor of allocating more capital to faster-growing categories such as organics," Lash wrote, adding, "this could occur in a more rapid fashion under its new ownership."

As consumer tastes have veered toward more healthful fare, so too have packaged food giants. General Mills (GIS) bought natural-foods maker Annie's last year. Before that, Campbell Soup (CPB) bought baby food maker Plum Organics and salad dressing brand Bolthouse Farms.
WhiteWave Foods (WWAV), maker of Silk soy and almond milk, rose 1.3%. Hain Celestial (HAIN) hit 66.35 early, but closed up 0.6% at 63.83.
Among larger food stocks, Mondelez International (MDLZ) — which split from Kraft in 2012 — rose 2.3%. General Mills edged up 1% and Kellogg (K) 0.3%.

"While the possible purchase of Kraft makes another deal likely impossible for several years, ultimately we believe Mondelez to be the clear 'next deal,'" noted Palmer. It would "reunite Kraft's global grocery brands (e.g. Philadelphia) and give Heinz's international business needed scale."
But combining brands might not always be the best strategy, as a recent PwC report cautions.

"It's no longer an asset-based game. Large, diversified food companies are struggling to compete with smaller, more focused enterprises," noted authors J. Neely and John Potter. "These companies need to be thinking beyond scale about what it is they do better than anyone else."The ink hasn't dried on the Kraft Foods (KRFT) merger with H.J. Tyson Foods (TSN) expects lower feed costs to boost profit in its poultry segment, but warned that a slowdown at West Coast ports could hurt livestock producers.
The meat giant also expects hog supplies to increase and prices to drop this year after a virus killed a vast number of pigs over the past year and a half.

While the strong dollar has been hitting other large U.S. companies, CEO Donnie Smith said on a conference call that lower prices internationally as well as cheaper chicken and pork are offsetting the currency headwinds.

Shares seesawed in the stock market today and were down 1.5% midday after rallying as much as 4.4%. Rival Hormel (HRL) was off 1.8%, Pilgrim's Pride (PPC) lost 4% and Sanderson Farms (SAFM) dipped 1.9%.

Tyson sees full-year sales of roughly $42 billion, a reflection of the integration of Hillshire Brands, the company said. Analysts expect $42.3 billion. The company also reaffirmed full-year EPS guidance of $3.30-$3.40, with the midpoint below analyst consensus of $3.40.
Fourth-quarter EPS rose 7% from a year earlier to 77 cents, topping estimates for 73 cents. Sales jumped 23.5% to $10.8 billion, beating forecasts for $10.4 billion.

Sales volumes for chicken, a key segment for the company, grew 3.1% during the quarter as consumers shift away from red meat in favor of lower-calorie items. Pork sales volume increased 1.1%, with higher demand boosting the sales price.

The company's prepared food segment sales volume jumped 89.5%, largely due to the Hillshire Brands acquisition. Sales volume for beef fell 2.7%, as the company processed fewer live cattle during the quarter.Tyson Foods (TSN) expects lower feed costs to boost profit in its poultry segment, but warned that a slowdown at West Coast ports could hurt livestock producers.The meat giant also expects hog supplies to increase and prices to drop this year after a virus killed a vast number of pigs over the past year and a half.While the strong dollar has been hitting other large U.S. companies, CEO Donnie Smith said on a conference call that lower prices internationally as well as cheaper chicken and pork are offsetting the currency headwinds.Shares seesawed in the stock market today and were down 1.5% midday after rallying as much as 4.4%. Still, the sports bar chain is expected to see no year-over-year growth in Q4 earnings, which are seen at $1.10 per share. Major averages pared losses from a late-morning slump to end mixed amid big merger deals and weak economic data.
The S&P 500 and Dow Jones industrial average closed fractionally higher, while the Nasdaq fell 0.4%. Volume ran lower across the board in the stock market today, according to preliminary data.
Meat products, staffing services and toymakers were the day's top gainers among the 197 industry groups tracked by IBD. Computer software and oil explorers suffered the biggest losses.

Tyson Foods (TSN) leapt 6% to a five-month high in heavy trade, nearing an early buy point of 44.10. The poultry processor reported fiscal Q4 earnings that topped estimates and revenue roughly in line with views. Sales got a boost from its June purchase of Hillshire Brands.

Among other chicken stocks, Sanderson Farms (SAFM) rose 1.5% in above-average volume, while Pilgrim's Pride (PPC), which had been in a bidding war with Tyson for Hillshire, gained 2% in slow turnover.

Allergan (AGN) jumped 5% to a record high in big volume after Actavis (ACT) said it's acquiring the Botox maker for $66 billion in cash and stock. That puts an end to Valeant Pharmaceuticals (VRX) and Pershing Square Capital Management's bid for Allergan.

Michaels Cos. (MIK) soared 3% in fast trade as it extended its gains for a fifth straight session. The arts and crafts store operator is expected to post Q3 earnings of 26 cents a share when it reports Thursday. Last week Morgan Stanley, which forecast EPS of 29 cents, upgraded the stock to overweight.

Investors took Hormel Foods (HRL) shares down early Tuesday after it reporting a fiscal fourth-quarter profit that was a penny less than expected, and its earnings guidance for the coming year was disappointing.
The maker of meat products and processed grocery food under the Skippy peanut butter, Jennie-O turkey brand and other well-known labels said earnings per share ex items rose 8.6% to 63 cents.

Revenue grew 9.5% from Q4 2013 to $2.54 billion, topping forecasts for $2.52 billion. A 9% rise in refrigerated food and 11% hike in the Jennie-O turkey product were partly offset by a drop in grocery and specialty items.
Hormel guided for fiscal 2015 EPS of $2.45-$2.55, below consensus of analysts polled by Thomson Reuters for $2.59 amid high pork commodity prices.
The company also raised its annual dividend 25% to $1 from 80 cents a share, its 49th consecutive annual dividend increase.

Hormel shares fell 4.3% to 51.79 in Tuesday morning trading in the stock market today. The meat and grocery giant's stock had hit a series of all-time highs in the run-up to its Q4 earnings, most recently rising to a 55.29 closing high Nov. 19.
BMO Capital, however, downgraded its stock to market perform (neutral) from outperform Nov. 6, saying its growth rate did not justify its lofty stock price.
Tyson Foods (TSN), the nation's top chicken producer, jumped 6% Nov. 17 after it reported better-than-expected earnings.

Big cap stocks such as Apple were market leaders Thursday amid an improving jobs market and falling oil prices.

Apple (AAPL) was up 1.6% in 32% higher volume than usual on the stock market todayhttps://www.investors.com/stock-market-today/. DigiTimes, citing industry sources, reported that Apple has ordered enough chips to make up to 40 million Apple Watches, which are expected to debut around Valentine's Day.
Analysts at Bernstein raised their price target on Apple to 120 from 110 Thursday and maintained an outperform rating, citing Apple Watch prospects.
And a new job posting for the Cupertino, Calif., tech giant indicated that it's looking to hire a Web developer to bring its Maps services to the Web.

Chinese online gaming company NetEase (NTES), a smaller-sized big cap with a $12.77 billion market value, reported third-quarter earnings late Wednesday. The company recorded its fourth straight quarter of rising earnings and sales as all three of its business segments — online games, advertising and e-commerce — saw strong growth.

Greenbrier (GBX), which makes makes railroad cars, rose nearly 3% in 70% higher volume than usual as demand for railroad tank cars continues to grow despite declining oil prices. Greenbrier's order backlog recently rose to the highest ever amid increasingly diverse array of shipments, including chemicals, grain, autos and construction gear.
RBC Capital initiated Tyson Foods (TSN) early Thursday at an outperform rating with a 48 price target, pushing its stock up nearly 3% in 24% higher volume.
The parent of Hillshire Farm, Jimmy Dean and other branded products is the world's largest supplier of chicken products and one of the biggest meat companies.
U.S. consumers have trended toward chicken as a healthy alternative to other meats, and increasingly affluent consumers in China and emerging nations are buying more meat products.

As the stock market plunged Tuesday on concerns over the impact of a weaker Europe on companies that do business there, some U.S.-serving meat-and-potato stocks held up relatively well.
And a coffee company, Keurig Green Mountain (GMCR), got a jolt as Goldman Sachs initiated coverage with a "buy."

Even with shares down slightly on Tuesday, fresh-egg producer Cal-Maine Foods (CALM) is up nearly 10% since September 29, when it reported higher selling prices and strong demand for specialty eggs in its last quarter.
Chicken producer Tyson Foods (TSN) is up more than 9% since then, even with shares down around 1% Tuesday.
On October 2, JPMorgan handed Tyson an "overweight" rating and a price target of 49 on better-than-expected earnings over the next few quarters.
Of 197 industry groups tracked by Investor's Business Daily, two food groups are in the top 10: Food-Meat Products and Wholesale-Food.

Cal-Maine, the top producer of fresh shell eggs in the U.S., is the highest-ranked stock in the former group, with a Composite Rating of 99, the highest possible. The group itself is No. 9. Tyson has a CR of 97.
Single-serve coffee company Keurig is the top name in the Wholesale-Food group, which is ranked No. 10.

Stocks opened in the hole, then quickly turned mixed on Monday, with weak economic news and a flurry of heavy merger activity at the center of early trade.
The Nasdaq narrowed its early loss to 0.1%. The Dow Jones industrial average and S&P 500 each shed thin losses to post fractional gains.

The stock market today, like most global markets, felt some early pressure from disappointing third-quarter GDP numbers from Japan. The New York Federal Reserve's Empire State Manufacturing Survey rose for November, but also came in weaker than expected.

Nationwide, industrial production slipped 0.1% in October, the Federal Reserve reported. That was down from a (downwardly revised) 0.8% gain in September and below projections for a 0.2% expansion. Utilization of production capacity also contracted more than expected — 78.9% vs. estimates for a flat performance at 79.3%.
Merger news drove a swirl of big stock moves in early trade. Baker Hughes (BHI) surged 9%. Halliburton (HAL) dived 10%. DreamWorks Animation (DWA) plummeted 15%.
On the upside, Hasbro (HAS) climbed 5%, and Allergan (AGN) jumped 7%.
In earnings news, Tyson Foods (TSN) rose 2% on healthy fiscal fourth-quarter results. Sturm Ruger (RGR) slipped 2% after wide misses on earnings and revenue.
Tata Motors (TTM) swept up 6%, with no clear news driving the move. The big-volume gain cracked the stock past a 47.76 buy point in a two-month, cup-with-handle base.

Chip designers Ambarella (AMBA) and NXP Semiconductors (NXPI) jumped 2% each to lead the IBD 50 list. Ambarella is extended and just below new highs after a rebound from 10-week support. NXP is just above a 73.92 buy point from a six-week cup base.

Sawmill titan Boise Cascade (BCC) fell 3%, the biggest drop among IBD 50 stocks. Major averages pared their losses in the final hour of trading but still closed modestly lower after a seesaw session.The Nasdaq and S&P 500 each gave up 0.3%, while the Dow industrials slipped 0.2%. Volume swelled across the board in the stock market today, according to preliminary figures.Stocks gave up early gains amid disappointing economic data. The Case-Shiller home price index rose 6.7% in July, below June's 8.1% increase and forecasts for a 7.5% gain. Consumer confidence fell to the lowest reading since May.Meat products stocks, up 2%, outperformed among IBD's 197 industry groups. Cal-Maine Foods (CALM) rose 3% in above-average volume. It reversed higher on Monday after reporting quarterly results that topped views. The stock is 2% off its recent high and up 38% from a 64.32 flat-base buy point it cleared in May.Among other meat processors, Hormel Foods (HRL), Tyson Foods (TSN) and Sanderson Farms (SAFM) each climbed less than 2%. Other food-related groups also scored gains Tuesday, including dairy products, confectionery and alcoholic beverages.Solar, oil and gas, and automotive equipment makers underperformed. Gentherm (THRM) skidded 10%, Magna International (MGA) 4%, Borg Warner (BWA) 3% and Delphi Automotive (DLPH) 2%, all in heavy volume, as Ford's (F) profit warning late Monday stoked worries that new car sales may be slowing down .Harman International (HAR), which makes audio gear such as speakers, CD players and subwoofers for the automotive and other markets, sank 4%. The stock undercut the low of a flat base it had been forming since mid-July.Follow Nancy Gondo on Twitter: @IBD_NGondo.

Hormel Foods (HRL) reported a meaty quarterly profit increase, topping analyst forecasts and driving shares up Thursday. The maker of Spam, Skippy peanut butter and Jennie-O Turkey said fiscal third-quarter earnings climbed 21% vs. the same quarter a year ago to 51 cents per share, beating by 3 cents. Revenue grew 5.6% to $2.28 billion, topping views of analysts polled…
,P.Tyson (TSN) shares hit an eight-week high following solid third-quarter sales and the $575-million sale of its Brazil and Mexico poultry operations to Pilgrim's Pride (PPC) majority owner JBS.

The meat processor's Q3 earnings rose 8.7% to 75 cents a share, falling short of views for 78 cents, while revenue rose 10.9% to $9.68 billion, beating estimates for $9.47 billion. But the almost 9% earnings gain is a decline from four straight quarters of 27% earnings growth or higher.
Shares of the company surged 5% in the stock market today. Pilgrim's Pride, which lost to Tyson in the bidding war for Hillshire Brands, was little changed.
Tyson's deal with JBS will close by the end of 2014 and includes three plants in Mexico and three plants in Brazil.
"Although these are good businesses with great team members, we haven't had the necessary scale to gain leading share positions in these markets," said CEO Donnie Smith in a release.

"In the short term, we'll use the sale proceeds to pay down debt associated with our acquisition of Hillshire Brands. Longer term, we remain committed to our international business and will continue to explore opportunities to extend our international presence."

The run-up in pork raw material inputs negatively impacted the prepared foods segment, said Tyson, but the beef and pork segments did well this past quarter. The company said the chicken segment encountered isolated issues at a few plants and could have had a stronger performance.
Tyson expects to see at least 10% earnings growth in 2015, better than the consensus estimate of 9% earnings growth next year.

A few weeks ago, the discovery of a rooster fertility issue in Aviagen Group's Ross male ruffled feathers and pushed up prices. Despite its acquisition of salad-dressing maker Wish-Bone, Pinnacle Foods (PF) reported mixed Q2 results. The Duncan Hines and Vlasic pickles parent's per-share earnings rose 14% to 33 cents, matching views, but revenue rose 8.6% to $617.8 million, falling short of analyst estimates for $629.3 mil. Shares of Pinnacle Foods fell 0.4% to 30.81 in early afternoon trading on the stock…
Stocks turned mixed in afternoon trading Tuesday as oil prices pared some of the prior day's losses, tempering concerns about the global economy.

The Dow Jones industrial average was down 0.6% and the S&P 500 lost 0.3%, while the Nasdaq rose 0.2%. All indexes were down by more than 1% earlier. Volume was running above Monday's levels on both the Nasdaq and the NYSE.

U.S. consumer confidence jumped to an 18-month high, and the number of job openings increased in October, according to data released Tuesday. However, investors are worried that sinking oil prices signal that global demand is slowing. Crude prices rebounded about 1% after sinking 4% Monday to a five-year low.

In the stock market today, Envestnet (ENV), a Web-based provider of software for financial advisers, was down 4% in huge volume after falling as much as 10%. The stock managed to hold onto support at its 50-day moving average.

Drug stocks took a hit. Lannett (LCI) dropped 11%, slicing through its 50-day line in heavy volume and falling below a 46.84 cup-with-handle buy point. It has fallen 9% from the buy point, marking a sell signal.

On the upside, AutoZone (AZO) jumped 5% to a new high in heavy volume after the auto parts retailer posted better-than-expected earnings for its fiscal first quarter. Chicken processor Pilgrim's Pride scaled a new peak and rival Sanderson Farms held near its recent high Tuesday despite this week's market turmoil.Like many other stocks in the IBD Spotlight screen, Pilgrim's Pride (PPC) is out of buying range after clearing a 19.33 cup-base buy point in March. It's also well-extended from a second rebound off its 10-week moving average.Sanderson Farms (SAFM) is extended after multiple rebounds off its 10-week line following its December breakout past a 70.79 buy point.Both stocks are leaders in the Food-Meat Products industry group, which was ranked fifth out of 197 as of Tuesday's IBD. The group was among few groups that were able to rise Tuesday despite the market's sell-off.The industry has gotten a lift from rising meat prices and Tyson Foods' (TSN) recent purchase of hot dog and sausage maker Hillshire Brands (HSH), which has fueled speculation about more takeovers in the industry.Pilgrim's Pride has posted strong profit growth, ranging from 81% to 511% in the past four quarters, much better than year-earlier levels. But profit for the latest quarter is expected to decline 20% to 59 cents a share, and full-year earnings are seen declining 8%.Sanderson Farms has also enjoyed four quarters of strong profit growth, including a better-than-expected 108% jump in the latest period. For the year, profit is expected to rise 68% to 9.53 a share.Both stocks show strong relative strength lines and Accumulation/Distribution Ratings of A, indicating strong demand for the shares.Investors should wait for these stocks to correct and form new bases with fresh buy points. Buying now would be risky, given their strong advances. But any new bases that they form would be late-stage, which is another concern.

Summer is the perfect time to throw a steak, hamburger or hot dog on the grill. But this year, rising prices for those treats threaten to sour the summer barbecue season. Pork costs about 15% more at supermarket counters than it did a year ago. Beef is up 13% and rising. On the white meat side, the price of chicken…

It's time to celebrate! Fireworks and backyard grills are hot for the Fourth of July weekend, just what America's favorite (and only) publicly traded hot dog specialty company needs. That's because Nathan's Famous (NATH) hot dogs shares were cold Thursday. Nathan's Famous, which sponsors the annual July 4 hot dog eating contest on Coney Island, is nearly 100 years old,…

The new-high list was thin Tuesday because of the market's sharp sell-off, but a few stocks managed to make the list. Two Argentine banks, Grupo Financiero Galicia (GGAL) and BBVA Banco Frances (BFR), were among them. Galicia gained 0.29 to close at 15.71 while Banco Frances was up 0.09 to 12.59. Stocks raked up narrow gains Monday as the S&P 500 pushed to a fourth consecutive record close.
The tech sector started strong and helped the Nasdaq to a 0.3% gain. The Dow Jones industrial average and the S&P 500 clocked gains of 0.1% apiece. The indexes closed well off session highs.
Small caps were the stars of the session, with the Russell 2000 ending ahead 0.8% and the S&P 600 finishing with a 0.7% gain.
Preliminary data showed volume ended mixed, up 13% on the Nasdaq and down 5% on the NYSE.

Acquisitions drove a healthy slice of the action on the stock market today, with Tyson Foods (TSN) beating out Pilgrim's Pride (PPC) in a bidding war for Hillshire Brands (HSH). Merck (MRK) announced that it would snap up Idenix Pharmaceuticals (IDIX) in a $3.85 billion deal.

A number of chip stocks knocked off nice gains, stirred by Analog Devices' (ADI) announcing its plan to acquire Hittite Microwave (HITT). Hittite — a maker of chips used in cell phones and satellites — vaulted 28% on news of the $2 billion offer. Analog Devices climbed 5% in powerful trade to clear a flat-base buy point of 54.46.
Among other chipmakers, Integrated Device Technology (IDTI) and Applied Micro Circuits (AMCC) popped 4% each.

Keurig Green Mountain (GMCR) shed 7% in strong trade. The loss gave back most of Friday's 8% gain. The stock is forming an angular cup-with-handle base with a 123.72 buy point.Stocks raked up narrow gains Monday as the S&P 500 pushed to a fourth consecutive record close.The tech sector started strong and helped the Nasdaq to a 0.3% gain. The loss gave back most of Friday's 8% gain. The stock is forming an angular cup-with-handle base with a 123.72 buy point.
Stocks fell moderately Tuesday but traded in a tight range and held near highs with less than two hours remaining in the session.
The Nasdaq and Dow Jones industrial each lost 0.1% while the S&P 500 fell fractionally. Volume on the NYSE was tracking 6% higher than Monday. Nasdaq volume fell 2%.

In the stock market today, several chip stocks outperformed in heavy volume. Skyworks Solutions (SWKS), a Leaderboard stock at Investors.com, jumped 6% after the company issued bullish earnings and sales guidance for the current quarter. The company said it expects to continue to benefit from growing interest in Web-connected appliances and devices, otherwise known as the Internet of Things.
Meanwhile, chip-equipment makers Applied Materials (AMAT), and Lam Research (LRCX) were beneficiaries of positive comments by Jefferies.
Applied Materials extended gains after a recent cup-with-handle breakout over 20.51. Shares rose 4%. The stock is near the high end of a buy range, 4% above the buy point.
Lam Research added 3%. The stock extended 9% above a flat-base buy point of 59.04.

Meanwhile, Hillshire Brands (HSH) gapped up for the second time in six trading sessions. Shares surged 9% after Pilgrim's Pride (PPC) raised its bid for the company to $7.7 billion, or $55 a share. The new offer tops an earlier bid from Tyson Foods (TSN) that valued Hillshire at $50 a share.

Elsewhere, automakers didn't move much despite reporting better-than-expected U.S. new-car sales in May. Sales at Nissan (NSANY) jumped 18.8% from a year ago; Toyota (TM) rose 17%; Chrysler, owned by Fiat, climbed 16.7% and General Motors (GM) increased 12.6% from a year ago.

Ford (F) showed the slowest growth, up just 3%. Stocks were tightly mixed at Tuesday's open, with earnings reports driving much of the early action.
The Nasdaq, hamstrung by Baidu's (BIDU) 14% decline, fought with a fractional loss. The Dow Jones industrial average and the S&P 500 each added 0.2%.
Volume was soft, down 12% on the Nasdaq and 17% lower on the NYSE, compared to action at the same time Monday.

The stock market today has an eye on the Federal Open Market Committee, which is meeting in Washington but not expected to generate any news until the policy announcement scheduled for 2 p.m. on Wednesday.

Other economic news began with home prices, which were effectively flat in May, according to a 4.9 reading for the Case Shiller 20-City Home Price Index. Economists had expected a reading of 5.6. April's number was revised a notch higher, to 5.

The Conference Board's Consumer Confidence Index also fell, dropping to 90.9 in July, down from June's 101.4 tally, which was revised lower to 99.8. Economist consensus projected a very slight dip, to 99.6, for July.

A more positive note from researcher Markit reported the services sector of the economy improved in July. The preliminary estimate for its PMI index rose to 55.2, up from a 54.8 reading in June. Consensus had looked for a no-change number of 54.8.
In stocks, reactions were generally positive as quarterly reports rolled out from a broad range of companies.

Ford (F) and heavy truck maker Paccar (PCAR) climbed nearly 2% each. GrubHub (GRUB) jumped 3% after its Q2 report. Norway's state-owned oil producer Statoil (STO) jumped more than 2% on its second-quarter results.

Baidu (BIDU) posted the news-leading decline, with shares diving 14% after the company reported a Q2 earnings miss late Monday. The drop put shares down 17% so far for the week, and far below critical levels of support.

Cummins (CMI) powered up almost 4% after the diesel engine maker easily beat analysts' second-quarter sales and earnings projections. Management held to its prior revenue guidance for the year, which is consistent with consensus views. The stock has been in a deepening consolidation since June last year.

United Parcel Service (UPS) swept up nearly 4% as its earnings beat consensus estimates. Revenue stopped short of expectations, but management backed its prior EPS range of $5.05 to $5.30 for the year, and said it would come in near the top of that range. The stock has been crawling along the bottom of a flat consolidation and fighting to retake 10-week support since January.
The IBD 50 list opened the session evenly split — half up, half down at the start of trade.
Horizon Pharma (HZNP) and Blackhawk Network (HAWK) led the group, up more than 2% each. United Therapeutics (UTHR) grabbed the low post, dropping almost 4% after a mixed second-quarter report.

JetBlue Airways (JBLU) slipped nearly 4% after 132% EPS growth met Q2 expectations, but an 8% revenue gain stopped short of consensus estimates. The food fight on Wall Street keeps expanding, and investors signaled that they expect it to get even bigger. Tyson Foods, salivating over Hillshire Brands' prepared foods, offered on Thursday to acquire it for $6.8 billion, including assumed debt, or $50 a share in cash.

That trumps the $6.4 billion, $45-a-share cash bid from Pilgrim's Pride (PPC) for Hillshire (HSH) earlier this week. That in turn came on the heels of Hillshire's proposed $6.6 billion merger with Pinnacle Foods (PF).

"Hillshire's bid for Pinnacle last week (plus) the end of tax implications from Sara Lee spin are the key catalysts from a timing perspective," said Miller Tabak analyst Tim Tiberio via email. "HSH is attractive to TSN & PPC, as the company would enable them to fulfill their ambition of becoming a leading packaged meat company (higher margins, more stable cash flow and leading brand talent from Hillshire)."
Household Names

While top chicken processor Tyson (TSN) has several brands for steak, tortillas and deli meats, Hillshire would bulk up its prepared foods. It boasts several popular supermarket lines, including Ball Park hot dogs, Sara Lee frozen bakery goods, and Jimmy Dean and Hillshire Farm sausages.
Adding Hillshire also would add "significant synergy opportunities in production, logistics and sales," Tyson said in an investors' presentation Thursday.
Stephens analyst Farha Aslam also sees takeover synergies in a research note, singling out Tyson's pork business as one that would benefit from "better raw material utilization."

Pilgrim's sees Hillshire brands adding retail strength to its existing food-service and grocery-store lines. On the food-service end, Pilgrim's supplies fresh chicken to delis and restaurants, and prepared chicken to chains like Yum! Brands (YUM) and Chick-fil-A. Pilgrim's also has expressed interest in pursuing "joint opportunities in school lunch and institutional" areas.
Bidding War Likely
Hillshire will reportedly review the Tyson offer in addition to the Pilgrim's bid, but more feathers may be shed before a new pecking order is set.

"Based on our indirect following of (Pilgrim's Pride majority owner) JBS over the years, we would find it highly doubtful that the management team will let Hillshire go without, at least, another round of bidding," Tiberio wrote in a note. "JBS' aspiration to use Pilgrim's balance sheet as a growth vehicle in North America is very well known."
Hillshire shares rose 17% to 52.76. That's significantly above Tyson's offer, suggesting investors expect a beefed-up bid. Hillshire is up 42.5% this week.
Tyson shares rose 6% to 43.25.
Pilgrim's Pride fell 1% to 25.09.
Earlier in May, Hillshire offered to buy Pinnacle Foods for $6.6 billion including debt. Pinnacle brands include Vlasic pickles, Duncan Hines cake mixes and Birds Eye frozen vegetables.
The Tyson and Pilgrim offers for Hillshire assume the Pinnacle deal won't happen. Pinnacle shares edged up Thursday but fell 5% Tuesday on Pilgrim's bid.

Tyson's fellow chicken processor Sanderson Farms (SAFM) said Thursday that it earned $2.21 a share, up 108% from a year earlier and beating fiscal Q2 views by 51 cents. Sales rose 6% $660.72 million, beating views of $625.7 million. Shares rose 3% to 90.34, hitting a new high intraday.The food fight on Wall Street keeps expanding, and investors signaled that they expect it to get even bigger. The major averages ended mixed but closed near their intraday highs Tuesday after trading in a fairly narrow range.

The Nasdaq and Dow finished fractionally higher, while the S&P 500 was barely lower. Facebook (FB), which jumped 5%, was the most active on the Nasdaq. Volume was slightly heavier than Monday on both exchanges in the stock market today, according to preliminary data.

Illumina (ILMN) extended its gains for a seventh straight session with a 3% advance in twice normal turnover. The stock is 9% above a 161.10 buy point of a cup-with-handle it cleared last week in heavy trade.

YPF (YPF) gained 3% in busy action and is now 4% past a 31.63 cup-with-handle entry. The stock initially broke out in early May before pulling back to its 50-day moving average. The Argentine oil and gas driller has posted 42% or better profit growth the past three quarters. Analysts expect a 188% gain in Q2.

On the downside, Tyson Foods (TSN) fell 4%, nearing its 200-day moving average in more than triple usual trade. Credit Suisse cut the stock to underperform from neutral, citing the $63 a share the meat processor will pay for Hillshire Brands (HSH). Tyson on Monday slumped 6% after winning a bidding war vs. Pilgrim's Pride (PPC) for Hillshire.

Verint Systems (VRNT) gapped down and dropped 5% in heavy volume as it toppled from its Monday closing high. The security software maker on Monday announced a proposed public offering of 5 million common shares and $300 million of convertible senior notes due 2021.

The stock initially broke out in early May before pulling back to its 50-day moving average. The Argentine oil and gas driller has posted 42% or better profit growth the past three quarters. Analysts expect a 188% gain in Q2.On the downside, Tyson Foods (TSN) fell 4%, nearing its 200-day moving average in more than triple usual trade. Credit Suisse cut the stock to underperform from neutral, citing the $63 a share the meat processor will pay for Hillshire Brands (HSH). Tyson on Monday slumped 6% after winning a bidding war vs. Pilgrim's Pride (PPC) for Hillshire.Verint Systems (VRNT) gapped down and dropped 5% in heavy volume as it toppled from its Monday closing high. The security software maker on Monday announced a proposed public offering of 5 million common shares and $300 million of convertible senior notes due 2021.Follow Nancy Gondo on Twitter at https://twitter.com/[email protected].

Stocks held moderate gains going into the noon hour Wednesday, with energy stocks leading the way on a sharp rise in oil prices. The Nasdaq rose 0.6%, the S&P 500 rose 0.9% and the Dow Jones industrial average lifted 0.8% in the stock market today. Volume was tracking higher than at the same time Tuesday on both the NYSE and Nasdaq.

Among IBD's 197 industry groups, energy groups were among the best performers. The U.S. oil and gas producers group rose 6%. Oil futures rose more than 3% after the government said oil stockpiles declined unexpectedly, signaling a rare reprieve from the oversupply that has driven down prices. OPEC also said it expects oil prices to rebound.

Despite a cheery earnings report and an after-hours pop Tuesday, Nike (NKE) reversed and headed lower. It was down 2% in above-average volume and struggled to hold its 50-day moving average even though several analysts had good words for the stock before the open. It's trading below a 133.62 buy point it cleared a few weeks ago.

Bed Bath & Beyond (BBBY) gapped down and was trading at a four-year low, off more than 4%. Before the open, Wedbush Morgan lowered its price target on the stock to 48 from 62. The stock has broken below 50, to the lowest since August 2011.
Among IBD 50 stocks, Veeva Systems (VEEV), a newcomer to the list, was the best performer, up 2%. The cloud-based medical software maker is forming a long base.
Another IBD 50 newcomer, electric utility ITC (ITC), also rose 2% and is forming a base. It has received multiple analyst upgrades in recent weeks.

Stamps.com (STMP) hit a 15-year high and is now extended from a flat base from which it broke out Dec. 15. After suitors stacked bids on top of one another like cuts of meat, Tyson Foods (TSN) triumphed with an offer of $63 a share, or more than $7.7 billion excluding assumed debt, for Hillshire Brands, the New York Times and Wall Street Journal reported Sunday night, citing sources. Pilgrim's Pride (PPC), majority owned by Brazilian meat processing giant JBS, had…

How far will the feathers fly in the latest round of Pilgrim's Pride (PPC) and Tyson's (TSN) fight for Hillshire Brands (HSH)? Days after Tyson threw its hat in the ring for Hillshire, Pilgrim's Pride raised its bid for the prepared-foods company to $7.7 billion. The new bid is for $55 a share in cash, above Pilgrim's earlier $45-a-share offer…
Stocks opened modestly higher Thursday despite mixed economic data.

The Nasdaq climbed 0.4% to its best levels since early April. The S&P 500 rose 0.2% to a record high. Meanwhile, the Dow Jones industrial average ticked up 0.1%. Volume was tracking sharply lower across the board in the stock market today.
Pending home sales rose 0.4% in April, missing expectations for a 1% increase. Stocks had little reaction to the report.
Earlier, the Commerce Department reported that U.S. economic growth contracted in the first quarter. But jobless claims came in better than expected.

Hillshire Brands (HSH) gapped up and bolted 16% after Tyson Foods (TSN) offered to buy the maker of Jimmy Dean sausage products for $6.1 billion or $50 a share. That trumped a bid made by Pilgrim's Pride (PPC) earlier in the week. Pilgrim's Pride fell 2%, while Tyson jumped 4%.
Palo Alto Networks (PANW) gapped up and surged 10% after late Wednesday's Q1 results and news of a lawsuit settlement. The stock opened well above a 72.60 buy point from a double-bottom base.

Michael Kors (KORS) fell 2% in fast trade. The stock staged a big upside reversal near its 50-day line Wednesday in the wake of its fiscal Q4 results. Michael Kors is forming a base with a 101.14 buy point.

Celgene (CELG) was off its session low, but still down 1% after being cut to neutral from overweight at JPMorgan. The S&P 500 was on track to finish at an all-time high as the major averages continued to hold their gains in late-afternoon trading Tuesday.
The Nasdaq was up 0.9%, the S&P 500 0.5% and the Dow Jones industrial average 0.4%. Volume in the stock market today was running higher compared with Friday's light pre-holiday trade.
Online travel, meat products and biotechs were among the biggest gainers.

Sanderson Farms (SAFM) was on track to notch a fourth straight up day as it added 2% to a new high in above-average turnover. Analysts expect the chicken processor to grow earnings 58% to $1.68 a share when it reports Thursday. Sales are seen as being flat.

Hillshire Brands (HSH) gapped up and soared 22% to a record high on massive turnover after Pilgrim's Pride (PPC) made an unsolicited offer to buy its rival for $45 a share. Pilgrim's was up as much as 7% early, but pared its gains down to 2%.
Tyson Foods (TSN) was up 4% in busy trade amid reports saying the meat processor may be pursuing acquisitions and that Hillshire could be a potential target.

Arris Group (ARRS) gapped up and rose 2% to a new high in volume 24% heavier than usual. Its stock is now 4% above a 30.47 cup-with-handle buy point. The cable industry gear maker has posted 80%-plus profit growth the past four quarters, boosted by its purchase of cable TV set-top box maker Motorola Home last year.

Stocks finished mildly lower Tuesday as neither bulls nor bears could find news that could excite them. Volume rose on both main exchanges, according to preliminary data.
The Nasdaq and the Dow Jones industrial average were off 0.1% as the S&P 500 fell by even less.
It was the third down day for the Nasdaq after a sharp rally. Each of the three days, the index has finished well off its lows of the day.

Skyworks Solutions (SWKS) rose rose 6% in brisk trade. It hit its highest level since December 2000. The company raised earnings and sales guidance and said it continues to benefit from the growing interest in Web-connected appliances, also known as the Internet of Things.

Hillshire Brands (HSH) gapped up again and finished nearly 10% higher after Pilgrim's Pride (PPC) raised its bid for the stock. The stock is up 55% since Pilgrim's Pride and Tyson Foods (TSN) started a bidding war for the company.

The IBD 50 stocks were about evenly split among winners and losers. The worst performer was Chinese Internet stock BitAuto (BITA), which operates websites that connect automobile sellers and buyers. It dropped 11%, spoiling a cup-base attempt.
Chip stocks were generally higher, among them Applied Materials (AMAT), which was 4% higher. Jefferies started coverage with a buy rating. The stock broke out of a cup-with-handle base.

Lam Research (LRCX), another chip stock, rose nearly 4% to an all-time high. Hormel Foods (HRL) reported less than savory second-quarter profit and issued weak guidance, driving shares down early Wednesday. The maker of meat products and prepared foods that include Spam, Skippy peanut butter and Jennie-O Turkey products earned 52 cents per share in Q2, lighter than the 56 cents Wall Street had expected. Revenue grew 14% to $2.45 billion, topping estimates…

Tyson Foods (TSN) is slated to disclose fiscal second-quarter earnings early Monday, and investors will be looking to see if the company can post a fourth straight quarter of double-digit earnings growth.The meat, poultry, pork and prepared-foods company is projected to record a 5% increase in revenue to $8.84 billion.Consensus of 10 analysts polled by Thomson Reuters is for earnings per share to leap 75% to 63 cents.Tyson's strong results over the past year have come despite challenges, including fresh outbreaks of bird and hog viruses in China and elsewhere.Not everyone is convinced Tyson can stay on the fast-growth track. BMO Capital Markets on Tuesday downgraded its rating from outperform (buy) to market perform (neutral). The bank cited what it considers Tyson's high valuation. Tyson stock has risen about 56% from a low of 27.33 on Nov. 4.On the company's first-quarter earnings call in late January, CEO Donnie Smith cautioned that Tyson faces headwinds this year.Smith told analysts that although consumers are becoming less defensive in spending, "I don't know of anyone who thinks that consumers will go back to their pre-2008 spending habits any time soon."Investors will look for clues on current pricing trends in the company's earnings report."Record high beef prices should continue through 2014," offsetting lower consumption, Smith said earlier this year. "Pork prices will also remain high due to lower supply. Chicken should continue to be the winner."Allianz Global Investors analyst Bryan Agbabian said in a report Wednesday that Tyson is a solid play on the increase in demand for chickens in the U.S. and globally, especially in China, the world's largest consumer market."Tyson is developing an in-country, in-China integrated production of chicken so that Tyson can then sell to not only the local market there, but also to the U.S.-based restaurants that are doing business there such as (Yum Brands (YUM)-owned) Kentucky Fried Chicken and McDonald's (MCD)," Agbabian said in the report.Tyson shares were up nearly 1% in Friday afternoon trading in the stock market. Its stock price hit an all-time high 44.01 on March 31 and has consolidated since in sync with a market correction.Among other large meat producers, highly rated Hormel Foods (HRL) was unchanged. Hormel sports a 92 IBD Composite Rating, which means it has outperformed 92% of all stocks on key metrics such as sales and profit growth in recent quarters.Fresh and frozen chicken products-maker Sanderson Farms (SAFM) climbed more than 2%. It boasts a 97 Composite Rating.Prepared- and fresh-chicken company Pilgrim's Pride (PPC) jumped 6% on bullish comments by CEO Bill Lovette during an earnings call with analysts Thursday.Follow James DeTar on Twitter: @IBD_JDeTar

Tyson Foods (TSN), the second-largest U.S. pork producer, made an unsolicited $6.8 billion offer to buy Hillshire Brands (HSH), trumping a competing bid from Pilgrim's Pride (PPC). Tyson is offering $50 a share, representing a deal premium of 35 percent, the Springdale, Ark.-based company said Thursday in a statement. It said it has financing for a takeover arranged with Morgan…

Stocks were poised for a higher open on this first trading day of November as a round of merger activity offset weak data out of China. Nasdaq 100 futures rose 12 points vs. fair value and S&P 500 futures climbed 2 points.
Futures on the Dow Jones industrial average rallied 23 points.
Stocks rallied for a fifth straight week last week and closed out the month of October with solid gains.

Over the weekend, China reported lackluster manufacturing data. The preliminary Caixin China manufacturing purchasing managers' index (PMI) came in at 48.3 in October, up from 47.2 in September. But readings under 50 signal contraction. China's official PMI came in at 49.8 in October, according to the National Bureau of Statistics. This marked the third straight monthly drop for the world's second largest economy.
Asian stock markets were lower, with the Shanghai composite and Hong Kong's Hang Seng losing 1.7% and 1.2%, respectively. Japan's Nikkei fell 2.1%.
In stock news, several companies announced deals.
TreeHouse Foods (THS) agreed to buy ConAgra Foods' (CAG) private brands business for $2.7 billion in cash. ConAgra shares surged 13% in premarket trading, while TreeHouse shares eased a fraction.

Visa (V) announced that it would acquire Visa Europe in a deal valued at more than $23 billion if certain targets are met. Visa Europe split from its parent company in 2007 before the credit card firm's initial public offering.

Separately, Visa also reported mixed quarterly results. It posted fiscal Q4 earnings of 62 cents a share, up from 55 cents a year ago. But it missed views by a penny. Sales climbed to $3.571 billion, barely edging views for $3.57 billion.
The firm also announced a $5 billion stock buyback program. Visa shares fell about 2% in premarket trading. The stock has had a tough time making progress from a 77.02 entry in a consolidation.

Dyax (DYAX) soared 33% on news that it would be acquired by British drug giant Shire (SHPG) for an initial $5.9 billion, or $37.30 per share, in cash. Shareholder may receive an additional $4 a share, depending on approval for its hereditary angioedema treatment.

Elsewhere, Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) fell 4% in premarket trading on news that it closed stores in the Northwest due to an outbreak of E. coli. Shares have already been under pressure recently on weak quarterly earnings.

On the economic front, reports on factory activity from Markit and the Institute for Supply Management will be out at 9:45 a.m. and 10 a.m. ET, respectively. Data on construction spending is also due at 10 a.m. ET in the stock market today.

JBS, the biggest meat producer, made an unsolicited $5.6 billion bid for Hillshire Brands — $6.4 billion including assumed debt — seeking to expand its sausage lineup and derail the company's acquisition of Pinnacle Foods.

JBS' Pilgrim's Pride (PPC) offered 45 a share. The deal is contingent on Hillshire (HSH) scrapping its $4.8 billion agreement to acquire Pinnacle (PF). Pilgrim's said it met with Hillshire in February and that it "has long been our desire to acquire the company."Brazil's JBS, which spent $17 billion on acquisitions in the past decade to overtake Tyson Foods (TSN), is resuming its takeover campaign less than a year after its last major deal. CEO Wesley Batista told Bloomberg News last week that JBS will keep expanding via more purchases as opportunities arise.In the U.S., JBS bought Smithfield Foods' beef-packing business in 2008 and took control of chicken processor Pilgrim's in 2009.Pulling For PorkJBS' "Holy Grail" is "to have exposure to all three segments of meat: poultry, beef and pork," said Bloomberg Industries analyst Ken Shea. "Today's unsolicited bid, if effected, would give JBS the third leg of a stool — a big piece of the pork market."Hillshire said in a statement that it will review the Pilgrim's offer and that it believes in the merits of the Pinnacle deal.Pilgrim's hadn't made an offer until now because it was focused on improving its operations and paying down debt, a person familiar with its thinking said.Pilgrim's and JBS believed promised cost savings for the Hillshire-Pinnacle deal were aggressive — especially considering Pinnacle's private-equity owners had already made cuts, according to the person.Shares of Hillshire, which makes Jimmy Dean sausages and Ball Park hot dogs, rose 22% to 45.19. Pilgrim's climbed 2% to 25.52. Pinnacle fell 5% to 31.48.Ricky Sandler, CEO of Eminence Capital, said Hillshire should engage with Pilgrim's and that today's proposal is superior to the Pinnacle transaction. Hillshire should see if there are other bidders and that interest may come from Tyson, Hormel Foods (HRL) and China's WH Group, he said. Sandler last week criticized the Pinnacle deal as expensive and said that his firm, a Hillshire holder, would vote against it.Pinnacle owns brands from Vlasic pickles to Wish-Bone salad dressings to Birds Eye frozen vegetables. Blackstone (BX) bought it for $2.2 billion about seven years ago and took it public again in March 2013.Pilgrim's would get a "pretty good deal" with Hillshire, said Craig Sterling, analyst at EVA Dimensions in New York. Hillshire has a 6.3% profit margin vs. 4.2% for Pilgrim's, he said.

Tyson Foods emerged as the winner in a bidding war for Hillshire Brands by offering $63 a share, or $8.5 billion, topping Pilgrim's Pride's  (PPC) offer by $1 billion, in one of a series of deals announced Monday. With 229 of the large-cap index's companies reporting by Friday, the blended revenue growth for Q2 reached 3.5%, the highest rate since Q4 of 2012, according to data provided by Thomson Reuters.…

Energy plays and meat processors were among a wide range of leading stocks hitting new highs Thursday. Sanchez Energy (SN) extended its gains for a third straight session and snared a new high as it rose 1.14 to 35.05 in triple the usual volume. The stock is now 11% above the 31.69 double-bottom buy point that it initially cleared on…

Many stocks marked new highs as the market rose Tuesday following the long holiday weekend. Buyout-related news and chatter boosted some names. Centene (CNC), leapt 3.02, or 4%, to a new high of 74.02 in heavy trade amid talk the managed health care service provider could be a takeover target. The stock is 9% extended past a 67.94 buy point…

Managers of the nation's best-performing funds of the past three months have slowed their buying in the latest reporting periods as stocks continued their correction. Tyson Foods (TSN) surged to an all-time high Friday after reporting strong quarterly results and offering a still-bullish sales outlook despite outbreaks of bird and hog viruses. A smaller list of new highs still gave investors a couple of high-rated stocks that cleared buy points Wednesday. Las Vegas Sands (LVS) broke out of a flat base. Shares of the world's largest casino company jumped 2.81 to 74.51, closing above the 73.59 buy point in heavy trading. Standard & Poor's Rating Services raised Sands' corporate credit rating to…
Stock futures were steady, pointing to a mixed open Wednesday.

Dow futures traded 22.4 points below fair market value. S&P 500 futures were down a fraction. Nasdaq 100 futures held 2.6 points into positive territory as Apple (AAPL), Priceline.com (PCLN) and Google (GOOG) all leaned higher in premarket trade.

The stock market today faces a quiet economic calendar, but a busy roster of earnings reports — especially in the after hours session. Among the early reports out, chip sector stocks were in sharp focus.
Chip equipment maker ASML Holding (ASML) climbed 6% in premarket action. The Netherlands-based company reported an 80% jump in Q4 revenue, with both revenue and EPS topping consensus views.
Management lowered Q1 revenue guidance below expectations. The stock has been consolidating and largely below its 10-week moving average since October.

Cree (CREE) climbed more than 3% ahead of the open. The chip and LED lighting products maker reported after Tuesday's close its fiscal Q2 EPS jumped 44% and revenue popped 20%, both well above expectations.
Q3 sales and earnings guidance was in line with expectations. Management noted "strong growth in LED fixtures and LED bulbs" was a key revenue driver.
The stock has been climbing, working to hold support since late November, after lopping through two sharp corrections.

On the downside, IBM (IBM) slipped 3% after reporting late Tuesday its revenue fell more than expected in Q4. IBM shares inched higher over the past five weeks, climbing off the bottom of a nine-month downtrend.
Chip developer Advanced Micro Devices (AMD) was down 7% after trimming a 10% tumble. Q4 earnings met, revenue beat consensus expectations, boosted by gaming console industry sales.
The company warned a Q1 revenue decline could dip below consensus expectations as those sales eased. The stock trades below 5.
Luxury handbag maker Coach (COH) was down 5% after trimming early losses. Both earnings and revenue missed consensus estimates in the New York-based company's fiscal Q2.
North American comparable store sales dropped 13.6% in a third straight quarterly decline. Sales in China rose 25%. The stock has been in a downtrend for 21 months.

Overseas, the Shanghai Composite vaulted 2.2%, rising further from Monday's five-month low after China's central bank moved to ease credit conditions ahead of the country's week-long Lunar New Year holiday in February. Hong Kong's Hang Seng index and Tokyo's Nikkei 225 gained 0.2% each.
Europe's major indexes held slight losses near mid-session.

The dollar edged up vs. the euro and the yen. Oil and natural gas continued higher, with oil pushing above $95 a barrel and natural gas up 2% and ahead 5% so far for the week. The stock has been consolidating and largely below its 10-week moving average since October.Cree (CREE) climbed more than 3% ahead of the open. The chip and LED lighting products maker reported after Tuesday's close its fiscal Q2 EPS jumped 44% and revenue popped 20%, both well above expectations.Q3 sales and earnings guidance was in line with expectations. Management noted "strong growth in LED fixtures and LED bulbs" was a key revenue driver.The stock has been climbing, working to hold support since late November, after lopping through two sharp corrections.On the downside, IBM (IBM) slipped 3% after reporting late Tuesday its revenue fell more than expected in Q4. IBM shares inched higher over the past five weeks, climbing off the bottom of a nine-month downtrend.Chip developer Advanced Micro Devices (AMD) was down 7% after trimming a 10% tumble. Q4 earnings met, revenue beat consensus expectations, boosted by gaming console industry sales.The company warned a Q1 revenue decline could dip below consensus expectations as those sales eased. The stock trades below 5.Luxury handbag maker Coach (COH) was down 5% after trimming early losses. Both earnings and revenue missed consensus estimates in the New York-based company's fiscal Q2.North American comparable store sales dropped 13.6% in a third straight quarterly decline. Sales in China rose 25%. The stock has been in a downtrend for 21 months.Overseas, the Shanghai Composite vaulted 2.2%, rising further from Monday's five-month low after China's central bank moved to ease credit conditions ahead of the country's week-long Lunar New Year holiday in February. Hong Kong's Hang Seng index and Tokyo's Nikkei 225 gained 0.2% each.Europe's major indexes held slight losses near mid-session.The dollar edged up vs. the euro and the yen. Oil and natural gas continued higher, with oil pushing above $95 a barrel and natural gas up 2% and ahead 5% so far for the week. Gold prices dipped near $1,241 an ounce.
Stocks opened in the hole, then quickly turned mixed on Monday, with weak economic news and a flurry of heavy merger activity at the center of early trade.
The Nasdaq narrowed its early loss to 0.1%. The Dow Jones industrial average and S&P 500 each shed thin losses to post fractional gains.

The stock market today, like most global markets, felt some early pressure from disappointing third-quarter GDP numbers from Japan. The New York Federal Reserve's Empire State Manufacturing Survey rose for November, but also came in weaker than expected.

Nationwide, industrial production slipped 0.1% in October, the Federal Reserve reported. That was down from a (downwardly revised) 0.8% gain in September and below projections for a 0.2% expansion. Utilization of production capacity also contracted more than expected — 78.9% vs. estimates for a flat performance at 79.3%.
Merger news drove a swirl of big stock moves in early trade. Baker Hughes (BHI) surged 9%. Halliburton (HAL) dived 10%. DreamWorks Animation (DWA) plummeted 15%.
On the upside, Hasbro (HAS) climbed 5%, and Allergan (AGN) jumped 7%.
In earnings news, Tyson Foods (TSN) rose 2% on healthy fiscal fourth-quarter results. Sturm Ruger (RGR) slipped 2% after wide misses on earnings and revenue.
Tata Motors (TTM) swept up 6%, with no clear news driving the move. The big-volume gain cracked the stock past a 47.76 buy point in a two-month, cup-with-handle base.

Chip designers Ambarella (AMBA) and NXP Semiconductors (NXPI) jumped 2% each to lead the IBD 50 list. Ambarella is extended and just below new highs after a rebound from 10-week support. NXP is just above a 73.92 buy point from a six-week cup base.

Sawmill titan Boise Cascade (BCC) fell 3%, the biggest drop among IBD 50 stocks.
